title: McCollum's Column: Beach volleyball, something sweet, weird history and a tragedy
text:
McCollum's Column: Beach volleyball, something sweet, weird history and a tragedy Posted: October 21, 2015 - 8:13pm 
From the special, the light and the sad, here’s another collection of “David’s Appetizers,” assorted musings on the sports scene: 
BEACH VOLLEYBALL 
At Monday’s Bearbacker luncheon, most of the questions directed at University of Central Arkansas women’s volleyball coach Jeni Jones concerned the addition of beach volleyball as a varsity sport next year. 
The Sugar Bears were on a road swing when Dr. Brad Teague, UCA’s athletic director, texted them the news after the university’s board of trustees made the official decision. 
“It was like Christmas in October when we heard the news,” Jones said. “All the players were extremely excited. Our current players couldn’t be more thrilled. I wish I had that opportunity when I played (at the University of Florida).” 
Jones said the sport creates professional opportunities in the United States. There are none in regular vollebyall. 
One major difference is the restrictions on coaching. There are only specific times a coach can talk to the players. 
It’s a two-on-two game with three sets of two players for each team. 
“The big thing is the beach game forces you to be a complete player because you’re playing both at the net and in the back and all over the court and working with one other player,” she said. “You have to develop all skills sets.” 
Jones said players on scholarship for regular volleyball can also play beach volleyball. Players who are on scholarship for beach volleyball cannot be play the indoor game. That’s to prevent a school from loading up on scholarships to increase the roster beyond maximum limits for regular volleyball. 
CANDY LAND 
If a youngster is seeking a sugar high, UCA’s homecoming on Halloween next week is the place to be. 
UCA officials will turn the tailgate area into a trick-or-treat area before the 6 p.m. game against Southeastern Louisiana. 
UCA will also try to set a world record for the largest bowl of candy (13,000 pieces of candy are planned). 
TOP TUNE FROM THE PAST 
To put the Chicago Cubs’ possibly ill-fated World Series quest into perspective: The last time the Cubs won the World Series (1908) one of the top songs on the charts was “Take Me Out to the Ballgame.” One of the greatest innovations that year was the paper cup and the Ottoman Empire was still alive. 
A TRAGEDY 
It’s a shocker that North Little Rock’s Altee Tenpenny was killed in an automobile accident in Mississippi. 
Tenpenny was probably the top high school recruit in Arkansas in 2013 and originally signed by Alabama. He had problems during his career and was dismissed and/or transferred from three programs, Alabama, UNLV and Nicholls, the latest after a weapons charge. 
His college career was characterized by poor decisions. It’s tragic that he never had a chance to get his life on track. 
His story is one that should catch the attention of young athletes everywhere. 
(Sports columnist David McCollum can be reached at 501-505-1235 or david.mccollum@thecabin.net )
